headline: Over 50 House Republicans attend fundraiser for Liz Cheney's challenger, Harriet Hageman
author: Aaron Navarro
sentences:

Aaron Navarro is an associate producer for the political unit at CBS News, focusing on House and gubernatorial campaigns as well as the census and redistricting.

Since she launched her campaign, she has been trying to portray Cheney as an "establishment" Republican whose actions against Trump are out of touch with Wyoming voters.
"That's clearly a vote of no confidence," Hageman told CBS News in February at the Conservative Political Action conference about McCarthy's endorsement against Cheney.
It's a sign that a sizable part of the House GOP caucus is eager to get Cheney out of office â€” less than a year since they ousted her from her leadership position.
If elected, Hageman said she would be aligned with the conservative House Freedom Caucus and possibly another conservative caucus, the Republican Study Committee.
More than 50 House Republicans were at a Washington, D.C., fundraiser on Wednesday night for Harriet Hageman, Rep. Liz Cheney's challenger in Wyoming.
Kentucky Senator Rand Paul, the lone senator on the initial guest list, claimed Hageman's popularity is "10 to one" over Cheney among Republicans.
Cheney is known as a critic of former President Trump, and has pushed back on his baseless claims that the 2020 presidential election was stolen.
Hageman has his backing and also that of McCarthy and Rep. Elise Stefanik, of New York, who replaced Cheney as House Republican conference chair.
"It was spoken very clearly by Harriet that she's running for the state," said Republican Congressman Mike Bost of Illinois outside the event.
Attendees paid at least $1,000 to get into the event, according to a copy of the invitation, which was first reported by Politico.
Other attendees of the fundraiser on Wednesday include Congressmen Madison Cawthorn of North Carolina and Jim Jordan of Ohio.
Cheney held a D.C. fundraiser earlier this month with Republican Sen. Mitt Romney, of Utah, that brought in over $526,000.
So I think she's sort of a woman without a party at this point," said Paul, who campaigned for Hageman earlier this year.
Wyoming election law allows voters to change their party registration and vote in a primary on the day of the primary.
The Hageman event was held at the home of Jeff Miller, a longtime McCarthy adviser who is now a lobbyist for Pfizer.
